Literature Review: Long-baseline neutrino oscillation experiments have been a cornerstone of neutrino physics research, offering a unique opportunity to study the properties of neutrinos and their interactions with matter. The precision measurements of three-flavor oscillation parameters, search for physics beyond the Standard Model, and study of neutrinos from astrophysical sources are among the extensive physics programs of these experiments. In this review, we will discuss the experimental considerations, including oscillation phenomenology, detector and experiment design, and analysis strategies, with a focus on the three-flavor oscillation measurements. We will also discuss current and future experiments, significant sources of systematic uncertainty, and mitigation strategies, emphasizing the importance of control of systematic uncertainty for precise measurement of long-baseline oscillation parameters.
